A new strategy is reported for enhancing the catalytic activity of nanoparticles for the sustainable development of organic transformations. Gel entrapped zinc oxide nanorods (GE-ZnO NRs) have been prepared and analyzed by FT-IR, XRD, TG, SEM, and EDX. Catalytic activity of ZnO NRs entrapped in gel was explored through the CSC reaction of aldehydes and acetophenone at room temperature in the hydrotropic aqueous medium. The catalyst was isolated by a centrifugation-free easy filtration process and re-used more than four times without any substantial loss in its catalytic activity. Use of low-cost biodegradable natural material, centrifugation-free separation of catalyst and isolation of the product without column chromatography are the attractive points of this sustainable approach. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords ZnO nanorods Heterogeneous catalysis Hydrotropes Ultrasound irradiation Claisen-Schmidt condensation reaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Today, green chemistry and nanotechnology attract much attention from researchers to find new methods for minimizing or eliminating the application of hazardous materials [1,2]. Meanwhile, developing green methods for organic transformations based on the recyclable efficient catalyst and green solvent have the most important challenge in green chemistry [3,4]. Among the CC bond formation reactions, Claisen–Schmidt condensation (CSC) reaction is an abundantly worthwhile CC bond-forming reaction in organic synthesis and the most important route toward chalcone derivatives. Chalcones are open-chain flavonoids compound with biological active sites due to α, β unsaturated carbonyl group [5,6]. From the literature, we realized that chalcones show many medicinal properties like anti-cancer, anti-malarial, anti-histaminic, anti-retroviral, anti-inflammatory, anti-oxidant, and anti-diabetic [7–11]. For these applicative reasons, researchers have to focus on the development of new techniques for the CSC reactions. There are many literature that reveals numerous examples of heterogeneous catalysts for the CSC reaction [11–15]. However, most of these synthetic transformations generally suffer from limitations such as expensive catalysts which are not easy to recycle and harsh reaction conditions having difficult procedures for isolation of the product. Therefore the discovery of a new catalytic system with an easy workup procedure is highly desirable. In present scenarios, zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnO NPs) as a catalyst has received extra attention from researchers as it is nontoxic, less corrosive, and inexpensive [17]. Moreover, ZnO NRs also show innumerable applications as a catalyst owing to their safer, greener, and sustainable nature [18]. However, their implementation in an organic reaction as a catalyst is often limited due to its limitations i.e. aggregation and difficulty in separation from the reaction mixture. Aggregation results decrease in catalytic activity due to reduced surface area [19]. To overcome from this aggregation issue, we designed agar gel entrapped NPs by immobilizing ZnO NPs in an agar polymeric system [20]. The hydrophilic polymeric network of agarose in water has the ability to form gel which makes it more efficient [21]. Easily separable heterogeneous gel entrapped ZnO NRs are stable in an aqueous medium as well as in organic solvents [22]. Together with catalyst solvent also plays a considerable role in green chemical transformation. Through the principles of green chemistry, Water is an ideal solvent but due to its disadvantages, most researchers avoid the use of water as a medium [23]. To minimize this drawback, a sodium p-toluenesulfonic acid (NaPTS) as hydrotropic aqueous medium is used to create a hydrophobic environment that solubilizes organic reactants in an aqueous medium [24]. From the point of view of green methodology, the application of the ultrasound technique has been proficiently applicable in organic synthesis because it is efficient and safe. The formation of a cavity takes place due to the high frequency and intensity of sound waves resulting in the quick dispersion of NPs [25]. Ultrasound irradiation in organic synthesis not only enhances the rate of reaction and product yield but is also considered as a green and sustainable protocol [26]. In this work, we report a novel GE-ZnO NRs catalyst for CSC reaction under ultrasound irradiation in a hydrotropic aqueous medium which makes CC bond forming reaction more significant. To my knowledge, till today gel entrapped NPs have not been used for CSC reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of GE-ZnO ZnO NRs were prepared by a reported hydrothermal process [27]. A mixture of ZnO NRs (0.162 g) and double distilled water (5 mL) was placed under ultrasound irradiation to form a colloidal solution for 10 min. After the formation of the colloidal solution, a mixture of agar powder (2.5 g), double distilled water (25 mL) and colloidal solution of ZnO NRs (5 mL) was heated at 60 °C until the formation of viscous fluid with the help of energetic stirring process. Then the resultant viscous fluid was poured in petri dish and cooled at 0 °C to 5 °C in refrigerator. After the formation of the gel, small cubes of gel were constructed by cutting it with the help of a spatula (Fig. 1 ). Fine pieces of a thin layer of the cube of GE-ZnO NRs were further used as a catalyst for CSC reaction (Fig. 1d). 2.2 Synthesis of chalcone First aqueous (20%) hydrotropic solution was prepared by adding 1 g of NaPTS (solid) in 5 mL of distilled water and then a mixture of (1 mmol) aldehyde 1, (1 mmol) acetophenone 2, and 0.05 g GE-ZnO NRs were added in hydrotropic solution. This mixture was stirred for 5 min. under magnetic stirrer and then, the mixture was kept under ultrasonic irradiations at ambient temperature. After completion of the reaction, (monitored by TLC) catalyst GE-ZnO NRs were completely separated by a simple filtration process. The product obtained by diluting the hydrotropic medium with water was filtered and washed with water (10 mL) to escape completely from the hydrotrope. Obtained product was recrystallized by ethanol. The recrystallized products were well identified by 1H NMR as well as 13C NMR. 2.3 Swelling property Swelling degree (SD) was calculated by following formula [28], SD ( % ) = ( M w − M 0 ) / M 0 × 100 M0 and Mw are the before swelling and after swelling weights of gel respectively. 3 Results and discussion Firstly, The ZnO NRs have been prepared by a reported hydrothermal process with slight modifications [27]. The synthesized ZnO NRs were analyzed by XRD, TGA-DTA, EDX and SEM for their structural, thermal, elemental and morphological studies. After successful results, synthesized ZnO NRs were used in the formation of a gel. GE-ZnO NRs are prepared by using agar and water system (Scheme 1). The constructed GE-ZnO NRs also characterized by IR, XRD, TG, EDX and SEM. The resulting GE-ZnO NRs used as a catalyst for CSC reaction. 3.1 FT-IR analysis Comparative FT-IR spectra were illustrated in Fig. 2 for the identification of bonding information and functional group associated with ZnO NRs, Agar and GE-ZnO NRs samples. The only one peak at 525 cm−1 in Fig. 2a illustrates Zn-O bonding in ZnO NRs on the other hand Fig. 2b illustrates FT-IR of agar powder which shows broad peak around 3354 cm−1 due to –OH group and sharp peaks at 2977 cm−1 corresponds to –CH stretching, peak around 1637 cm−1 due to -OH bending vibrations and peak at 1067 cm−1 represent CO-C stretching due to glycosidic linkage present in agar macromolecule [29]. The occurrence of ZnO NRs and Agar macromolecule associated bonds in FT-IR spectrum of GE-ZnO NRs composite (Fig. 2c) strongly support the successful preparation of Gel entrapped NRs. 3.2 XRD analysis Fig. 3 illustrates comparison of XRD pattern of ZnO NRs synthesized by hydrothermal method and GE-ZnO NRs. XRD pattern of ZnO NRs (Fig. 3b) indicate that ZnO sample has a hexagonal rode-shaped crystal arrangement. The powder XRD data of ZnO NRs exhibits diffraction peaks at 31.79°, 34.42°, 36.29°, 47.55°, 56.61°, 62.83°, 66.35°, 67.94°, 69.06°, 72.59° and 76.92° which are similar to pure hexagonal phase of ZnO nanorods (JCPDS No. 36–1451). The size of the ZnO NRs was determined by using Debye–Scherrer formula [30] based on the XRD pattern (Supporting information) and it is approximately 42 nm. The high intensity sharp peaks of the hydrothermally grown ZnO NRs indicate high crystallinity. XRD of GE-ZnO NRs (Fig. 3a) also exactly overlapped with XRD pattern of ZnO NRs with additional broad peak at 2θ=18.18 corresponds to agar [31] which conforming unchanged morphology of ZnO NRs when entrapped in agar gel. 3.3 Thermogravimetric analysis Thermogravimetric (TG) characterization was studied to appraise the approximate content of the polymer chain of biomolecules of agar and the thermal stability of ZnO samples. Fig. 4 (a) displays the TG analysis for the ZnO NRs synthesized by hydrothermal process. As shown, in the figure only 1–2% weight loss was observed in ZnO NRs at 272 °C and 680 °C due to elimination of hydrate molecules. On the other hand, Fig. 4(b) of GE-ZnO NRs shows decomposition at 54 °C, 298 °C, and 888 °C. First, 20% decomposition at 56 °C is owing to an elimination of physically adsorbed water by the heating process [22]. Another time the major (60%) decomposition at 298 °C is due to the degradation of the polymer chain of biomolecules of agar [31]. At the last 10% weight loss was observed at 888 °C due to ZnO NRs[31]. This TG study supports the formation of GE-ZnO NRs. 3.4 SEM analysis The surface morphology of the ZnO NRs and GE-ZnO NRs were characterized by using SEM. ZnO NRs shows a hexagonal rod-shaped structure (Fig. 5 ), while GE-ZnO NRs has porous morphology (Fig. 6 ). Fig. 6(a) shows elongated sheet-like morphology while Fig. 6 (b, c) shows entrapped ZnO NRs in agar gel at comparatively high magnification. Farid et al. reported that, The bright spots on the surface of the agar in SEM images were due to the metal/ metal oxide NRs attached to the surface of agar [32]. Fig. 6 (b, c) SEM images at high magnification are evidence of the existence of ZnO NRs on the surface of the agar. 3.5 EDX analysis Moreover, the EDX spectra of the ZnO NRs signify the existence of Zinc and Oxygen only Fig. 7 (a). In contrast, EDX spectra of the GE-ZnO NRs signify the existence of Zinc, Oxygen, and Carbon Fig. 7(b). These observations, especially the presence of Carbon in the EDX of the GE-ZnO NRs illustrate the successful inclusion of ZnO NRs on the surface of agar polymer. 3.6 Catalytic application of GE-ZnO NRs The catalytic efficiency of GE-ZnO NRs was checked via synthesizing chalcones in GE-ZnO NRs/sodium p-toluene sulphonate (NaPTS) catalytic system. First, we carried out screening test for a suitable solvent for swelling of GE-ZnO gel and it was observed that water is the finest medium in comparison to other organic solvents like ethanol, dichloromethane, and acetic acid Fig. 8 [33]. But due to the lower solubility of reactants in an aqueous medium, we used an aqueous hydrotropic medium as a solvent and also checked the swelling property of NaPTS in water and surprisingly it was found that (20%) NaPTS/water shows faster swelling property than water Fig. 9 . Therefore it was used as a solvent system. The next, an equimolar amount of aldehyde 1 and acetophenone 2 was selected as a model reaction (Scheme 2) (Table 1 ). First we obtained negative results for the model reaction performed in absence of catalyst in ethanol and in hydrotropic aqueous medium. These negative results highly recommended the necessity of the catalyst. Then reaction was carried out in presence of ZnO NRs as catalyst and observed that reaction did not proceed efficiently in ethanol at room temperature as well as at refluxed state. Further we applied ZnO NRs in hydrotropic aqueous medium and obtained 66% yield. Here we observed that reactants are soluble clearly in aqueous hydrotropic medium but ZnO NRs get agglomerated due to presence of water. To avoid this fact we apply ultrasonic irradiations for the dispersion of nanoparticles, but then also we did not obtain the desired yield in a hydrotropic aqueous medium. To enhance catalytic activity of ZnO NRs we utilized gel entrapped ZnO NRs for the model reaction in 20% NaPTS under ultrasonication and surprisingly observed that reaction proceed smoothly with high efficiency. The agar used in the formation of the gel not only restricts aggregation of ZnO NRs but also increases catalytic productivity of NPs both by extending catalytic surface and through lots of hydroxyl groups present on the surface of biopolymers [29,34]. We also observed that ultrasonication plays a key role in this procedure due to its effective mechanism process including enhanced penetrating and swelling properties [25,26]. After optimized conditions, the model reaction was optimized for catalyst loading (Table 2 ). The use of less than or greater than 0.05 g GE-ZnO NRs diminished the quantity of the yield. The results are excellent at 0.05 g GE-ZnO NRs. A series of chalcones were synthesized by reacting various substituted benzaldehyde with acetophenone to check efficiency of this protocol (Table 3 ). The obtained results indicate that the yield of the product depends on the nature of the substituent effect. Indeed, the electron-donating group on the phenyl rings of aldehydes produced higher yields of chalcones as compared to one having an electron-withdrawing group. 3.7 Plausible mechanism A plausible mechanism for the CSC reaction catalyzed by GE-ZnO NRs has been suggested in Fig. 10 . First, ketone (having α-hydrogen atom) activated by Lewis acid cite of ZnO NRs and hydroxyl group of agar from nanocomposite to form enolate ion (II). In contrast, GE-ZnO NRs and hydroxyl group of agar make carbonyl carbon (aldehyde) more electrons deficient. Further nucleophilic attack takes place on electron deficient carbonyl carbon to generate a carbon-carbon bond (IV) and the formation of chalcone (V) takes place by protection and deprotection of hydroxide ion [35]. The NaPTS is act as weak Lewis base which provides basic medium solvent and hydrotropic micelle of Na-PTS helps to solubilize aromatic/aliphatic aldehydes and ketones in aqueous medium due to their amphiphilic property. Synergistic effect of GE-ZnO NRs and hydrotrope enhance the rate of reaction. We have also studied the contact angle of water with GE-ZnO NRs. Agar is a hydrophilic polysaccharide molecule with a planar structure, in which sugar rings with hydrophilic –OH group are located on both sides, so a low contact angle was observed by an agar gel with water [36]. We observed that contact angle decreased in case of gel entrapped ZnO NRs as compared to pure agar gel. It was due to fact that, in polymeric materials, the contact angle is decreased with an increase in density [37] (Fig. 11 ) which confirmed that hydrophilic character increases with the trapping of ZnO NRs in an agar [28]. We also observed that, In GE-ZnO NRs, the ZnO NRs entrapped in gel dose not leached out from the gel. 3.8 Recyclability For any catalyst recyclability and recovery are the most important factors in scientific reseach. The most important aspect of this GE-ZnO heterogeneous nanocatalyst is its recyclability. GE-ZnO NRs (catalyst) were separated by a simple filtration process after completion of the reaction. The product was separated by adding (1–2 mL) water in hydrotropic reaction mixture, and the solid product was filtered off. A recovered aqueous layer of hydrotropic medium was washed with ethyl acetate to separate organic reactant/product from it and then reactivated by adding required amount of NaPTS or by evoporation of water under vacuum [38]. Separeted GE-ZnO NPs was then washed with ethanol/water and recycled by using reactivated hydrotrope up to the fifth attempt (Fig. 12 ). The leaching of the catalyst was not seen even though it was recycled several times. Both, catalyst and hydrotropic medium can be recycled and reused several times without significant loss in the yield which strictly follow sustainable recyclability protocol. Table 4 compaire the efficiency of GE-ZnO NRs with some recently reported calalytic system. 4 Conclusion In this present work, GE-ZnO NRS has been successfully designed and developed as an efficient, inexpensive, and safe catalytic approach towards CSC reaction. Simple procedure for the preparation of catalyst and non toxic contents makes it green and sustainable as compared to other heterogeneous catalysts. Porous nature of the agar restricts aggregation of ZnO NRs and hydroxyl group present on the surface of agar enhance its catalytic activity by expanding active sites of the catalyst. Furthermore, the catalyst can be separated from the reaction mixture by a simple filtration method and reused several times without significant loss in the yield of various chalcones representing that this protocol is applicable to large-scale industries. coredata.dc:description: A new strategy is reported for enhancing the catalytic activity of nanoparticles for the sustainable development of organic transformations. Gel entrapped zinc oxide nanorods (GE-ZnO NRs) have been prepared and analyzed by FT-IR, XRD, TG, SEM, and EDX. Catalytic activity of ZnO NRs entrapped in gel was explored through the CSC reaction of aldehydes and acetophenone at room temperature in the hydrotropic aqueous medium. The catalyst was isolated by a centrifugation-free easy filtration process and re-used more than four times without any substantial loss in its catalytic activity. Use of low-cost biodegradable natural material, centrifugation-free separation of catalyst and isolation of the product without column chromatography are the attractive points of this sustainable approach.
coredata.dc:title: Gel entrapped ZnO nanorods: An efficient and sustainable catalyst for the Claisen-Schmidt condensation reaction in aqueous hydrotropic media
